AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-2.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The aim of this study was to describe a methodology developed to study the relationship among the spatio-temporal patterns of habitat utilization, feeding ecology and microplastics (MPs) contamination across the different ontogenetic phases of fishes belonging to different trophic levels and living along the riverine-estuarine-coastal food chain. The Goiana Estuary?s water column was examined for the seasonal and spatial variation of MPs and their quantification relative to zooplankton and demersal fish species contamination following the same sampling design. The density of MPs in the water column determines their bioavailability. Studies on MPs distribution in relation to spatial and temporal variation of environmental factors and fauna are increasing in quantity and quality. If the ecological strategies presented in this study were replicated in other estuary, comparisons could be made in order to describe how the ecosystems work. Standard protocols for sampling, extraction, enumeration and classification of MPs and others pollutant ingested by fishes have been developed and are presented here to incentive comparisons. Standardized and comparable sample designs and laboratory procedures are an important strategy in order to study and transfer managerial solutions among different sites and comparisons across time when studying the same environment.

Standardized and comparable sample designs and laboratory procedures are an important strategy in order to study and transfer managerial solutions among different sites and comparisons across time when studying the same environment.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: First insight into plastics ingestion by fish in the Gulf of California, Mexico

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Marine pollution

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Plastic particle occurrence in the digestive tracts of fishes from a tropical estuarine system in the Gulf of California was investigated. A total of 1095 fish were analysed, representing 15 species. In total 1384 particles of plastic debris were recovered from the gastrointestinal tracts of 552 specimens belonging to 13 species, and all consisted of threads, the majority of which were small microplastics (0.23 to 1.89), followed by large microplastics
(2.07 to 4.49), and few mesoplastics (5.4 to 19.86). Plastic particles were identified using ATR-FTIR spectroscopy. The mean frequency of occurrence of plastics in the gastrointestinal tracts of fishes from this system was 50.5%, which is higher than frequencies reported in similar systems in other areas. The polymers identified by ATR-FTIR were polyamide (51.2%), polyethylene (36.6%), polypropylene (7.3%), and polyacrylic (4.9%). These results show the first evidence of plastic contamination for estuarine biota in the Gulf of California.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Life-history guilds of fishes associated with estuaries: opportunism versus dependency

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The concept of estuarine dependence by various fish species has been widely discussed and written about by ichthyologists for decades. In this review we selected single, well studied species that have the potential of being classified as dependent on estuaries for survival of the taxon on each of the following continents ? Africa, Australia, Europe, North America and South America. The three main guilds used in our assessment are marine estuarine-dependents, estuarine resident-dependents and catadromous estuarine-dependents. Of the three categories reviewed by this study, diadromous taxa are perhaps the most dependent on estuaries as a physical environment, even though these species spend less time in estuaries when compared to marine or estuarine categories. This is particularly the case with estuarine resident species that complete their entire life cycle within estuaries and whose primary population is found in estuaries and not in adjacent freshwater or marine environments. We also provide an overview of which guilds can be regarded as estuary-dependent and which are estuary-opportunist. Issues that are related to estuary dependency by fishes in estuaries, for example, the existence of contingents within a species population and the impact of global/climate change on estuary-dependent species, are also discussed.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Past and present conservation of south American estuaries

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-3.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
South America possesses a variety of estuaries along both tropical and temperate coastal regions, with most of these systems facing uncontrolled urban settlement and industrial development pressures. This review examines the contamination of estuaries on the continent with metals, persistent organic pollutants, and solid wastes, as well as their accumulation and transference through the trophic web. Moreover, we emphasize that the damming
of rivers, dredging of estuaries, and deforestation of catchments results in alterations to the natural river flow and habitat losses, thus disrupting ecoclinal gradients and impairing the ability of estuarine fauna to move across connected ecosystems. We highlight how the loss in estuarine biodiversity and complexity has diminished biotic resilience and increased the potential for natural ?disasters. It is also apparent that conservation actions are
urgently required before environmental modifications exceed the capacity of estuarine ecosystems to recover from such major perturbations. We document that developing continents with many developing countries, such as South America, require legislation to support a healthy environment, and that more attention needs to be devoted to the social, economic and cultural aspects of traditional communities. We emphasize that plans and actions aimed at estuarine conservation must be based on consistent and statistically testable data that covers
natural flow regimes, cycles of environmental contamination, and their influences on estuarine organisms. Environmental protection initiatives for South American estuaries are still in their infancy and steps are required to promote their protection by reducing untreated wastewater disposal, managing exploitation of resources, using stakeholder and co-management approaches, introducing restoration protocols, and improving habitat protection.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Top predator feeding ecology and microplastic (MP) contamination on the far eastern South American coast: Evidence of MP trophic biotransfer

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-3.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Ecologia da contaminação de ecossistemas aguaticos

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
This study describes the feeding ecology, plastic debris contamination, and spatial
distribution of each ontogenetic phase of, the Caribbean sharpnose shark,
Rhizoprionodon porosus as a function of spatial-temporal parameters in the Western
South American coastal area. The density and biomass for all individuals, in a surface
drift gillnet fishery, were 1.3 ± 0.3 ind.day -1 and 877 ± 232 g.day -1 . Neonates, and
juveniles were captured during all seasons. Adults were largely caught during the late
rainy and early dry seasons, probably moving offshore to adjacent open waters during
the late dry season. The diet of R. porosus consisted mainly of fish (FO=71.8%). All
ontogenetic phases were contaminated by plastic debris (FO=100%). Among the plastic
debris detected in R. porosus, 91.6% were microplastics (MP) (< 5 mm), of which blue
fibers contributed 53.7%. The MP samples were analysed by Optical microscopy (OM),
Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and by the
Energy dispersion X-ray spectroscopy technique (EDS) and identified as polyethylene.
R. porosus has a high ingestion rate of MP compared to fishes of lower trophic levels. In
addition, many fishes within the stomach contents of R. porosus were themselves
contaminated with MP (e.g., Eugerres brasilianus, Harengula clupeola, Rhinosardinia
bahiensis, Anchovia clupeoides, Monacanthus ciliatus, Polydactylus virginicus,
Trachinocephalus myops, Eucinostomus melanopterus, and Lutjanus analis). The
piscivorous diet of R. porosus likely leads to accumulation of MP contamination in this
top predator through trophic transfer.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Comparisons between tropical and temperate estuarine ichthyofaunas of western Africa and eastern South America

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: This review examines the probable fish colonization processes that occurred when plate tectonics and continental drift created the South Atlantic Ocean between Africa and South America, beginning in the Late Jurassic and gaining considerable momentum during the Cretaceous. Initial fish colonization is likely to have occurred by tropical fish families utilizing the western Tethys Sea arm around North Africa to gain access to the growing epicontinental seaways and coastal zones between Africa and South America. Speciation by some of these taxa would then have occurred such that the southern temperate waters on both continents became occupied by a less species rich cool-water ichthyofauna. The current numerical family status for African and South American tropical estuarine ecoregions is 55 and 63 respectively, whereas the numerical status for temperate ecoregions is 32 and 36 respectively. A Bray-Curtis similarity matrix was created for both fish families and species from the selected tropical and temperate ecoregions. These cluster analyses showed that fish families on either side of the Atlantic were similar but that the species were not. Only a very limited number of mainly large teleosts (e.g. Megalops atlanticus) and elasmobranchs (e.g. Carcharinus leucas) occur on both sides of the Atlantic. The current large crossing distances of >3 000 km for most tropical coastlines, and >6 000 km for some of the temperate coastlines, restrict fish species transfers across this large oceanic basin.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Feeding ecology and microplastic contamination of plankton feeder fish species in a tropical estuary in the Eastern portion of South America, a region known for its unique ecological characteristics and high biodiversity
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Feeding ecology and microplastic contamination of plankton feeder fish species in a tropical estuary in the Eastern portion of South America, a region known for its unique ecological characteristics and high biodiversity

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: ANAIS DA ACADEMIA BRASILEIRA DE CIENCIAS

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: This study describes the distribution, feeding ecology and contamination by microplastics in the different ontogenetic phases of A. clupeoides and C. edentulus in the Goiana Estuary (Northeast Brazil). Adults of A. clupeoides showed the highest density in the upper portion of the estuary during the late dry, while juveniles in the lower portion during the late rainy. Therefore, the lower estuary was considered a nursery for this species during the late rainy season. The marine species C. edentulus showed also the highest density in the upper portion of the estuary during the late dry season. However, the absence of juveniles in the estuarine ecosystem suggests that the nursery area is in the adjacent coastal region. During the dry season, this marine species enters into the estuarine ecosystem to complete its life cycle, when it becomes influenced by neritic waters. The diet of all ontogenetic phases of A. cluepoides consisted mainly of Copepods and larvae of Gastropod, A. flexuosa larvae and Decapoda Zoe larvae. According to the frequency of occurrence (FO%) for adults of this species, the highest values of Copepoda were detected principally in the lower estuary during the beginning of the rainy season. While subadult specimens feed on A. flexuosa Larvae in the lower estuary during the early dry season. Subadults and juvenile?s specimens of A. clupeoides feed on Gastropod larvae in the middle estuary during the early dry season. Specimens of C. edentulus feed on mainly phytoplankton. Coscinodiscus sp, Actinopthycus sp. and Chaetoceros sp. were the preferred phytoplankton prey for subadults and adults. The adults feed mainly on Coscinodiscus sp and Actinopthycus sp in the lower estuary during the end of the rainy season. while the subadults prey on the same phytoplankton species in the same portion of the estuary during the late dry season. DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Ingestion of nylon threads by Gerreidae while using a tropical estuary as foraging grounds

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-LIVRO.TITULO-DO-LIVRO: Aquatic Habitat Ecology & Conservation: Continental and Marine Ecosystems Connectivity

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The ?Aquatic Habitat Conservation in South America? Symposium occurred during the XXI Brazilian Society of Ichthyology Meeting. The proceedings were published as a special issue in the Journal of Fish Biology (vol. 89, Number 1, June 2016). In this special issue, authors provided an analytical overview of problems faced by the conservation of fishes and aquatic habitats of South America. Habitat loss emerged as the greatest concern for all South American aquatic ecosystems, with a long list of causes related to unsustainable development models. Based on this finding, we would like to extend this topic to other continents, different climates, fauna and flora around the world. Our goal is to provide a comprehensive and multidisciplinary overview of variables that influence flora and fauna distributions and shape their ecological interactions within aquatic ecosystems. Thereby, this Research Topic aims to provide a discussion forum to better understand the factors that lead to the loss of aquatic habitats and its effect on aquatic communities and ecosystem functioning, as well as the efforts being made to promote restoration of these ecosystems.All topics related to aquatic habitat (marine and freshwater) ecology and conservation are therefore welcome. Local studies, as well as national and international efforts, to preserve and restore the functionality of aquatic ecosystems are invited and can be presented in the form of current research methods and findings, review articles, opinion pieces or expanded case studies and pilot programs designed to better understand the best practices of aquatic ecosystems management and restoration.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The coastline of Brazil stretches approximately 8,400 km, with a continental shelf area of 822,800 km2 and a declared Exclusive Economic Zone of approximately 4.5 million km2. Mangroves are the dominant coastal vegetation particularly in the north of the country, covering an area of 13,400 km2, totaling approximately 8 % of the global mangrove regions. Common marine fish include sardines, corvinas, snappers, croakers, tunas, lobsters, and shrimp. In 2005, 750,000 MT were landed, including 60,000 MT of mollusks and crustaceans (predominantly shrimp). Fishing is practiced both on a small and industrial scale. Fisheries production has decreased from about 1 million MT to the low current numbers in the last two decades, an indication of the over-exploitation of these resources. Long-term management plans are urgently required taking into consideration life cycles of the fish, to guarantee sustainable utilization of the resources by the local populations. Juveniles of many marine fish species use estuarine nursery habitats before moving as adult populations to the coastal waters. However data on numbers of individuals from the exploited populations, which spend their early life in the different estuaries is lacking. Thus it is not known whether all estuaries contribute equally to maintaining local stocks, or if adult stocks in the coastal waters rely on recruitment from only one, or more estuaries. This question has significant implications for coastal management and land-ocean exchange processes. Connectivity studies, using biogeochemical signals on fish otoliths, will contribute to our understanding of relationships between populations of marine and estuarine fish species and their population dynamics, and will help to distinguish between open and closed populations, information which is essential for stock assessment purposes and the design of marine and coastal protected areas. The findings will help clarify if the different estuaries are habitat patches habitated by

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-CAPITULO-DO-LIVRO: Distribution pattern of fish in a mangrove estuary

DETALHAMENTO-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-LIVRO: Mangrove Dynamics and Management in North Brazil

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-2.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The Caeté mangrove estuary results from of the interplay between marine and freshwater influences that dominate every aspect of the system as both external drivers and ecological stressors. The controlling marine influence is the semi-diurnal tidal rise and, the other end, the seasonal fluctuation of freshwater river basin flow. Fish assemblages can be described in relation to biomass, density, and number of species and the seasonal fluctuation of environmental variables (salinity, water temperature and dissolved oxygen). These variables change in the Caeté Estuary main channel and intertidal mangrove forest, at both high and low tide (macro-tide with range 4-5 m). The fish fauna of each habitat differ in density, biomass and species composition.

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: There are no strict limits on the spatial or temporal scale of a fish assemblage (Miller, 2002). It may be an assemblage in a single season and region (e.g., a fish assemblage of an estuarine main channel during the late rainy season) or at specific times and locations (e.g., fish assemblages among different estuaries in South America). Research on fish assemblages has sought to understand where, why, and when they occur and how these spatial and temporal distributions relate to patterns in reproduction, recruitment, and foraging. The seasonal variation in proportion and abundance of freshwater and marine fish species in fish assemblages in estuarine habitats is a result of both the seasonal variation of environmental gradients (e.g., salinity, temperature, turbidity) and a suite of biological variables, including ...

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Estuarine ecosystems are characterized by a constantly changing mixture of saltwater and freshwater (McLusky, 1989). The flux of saltwater and freshwater presents physiological challenges to estuarine organisms. Gradients of salinity, for example, restrict many animal species in the adjacent sea or rivers from entering estuaries. In highly stratified estuaries, denser marine water entering an estuary along the bottom gradually mixes vertically with the outgoing surface flow of freshwater. Environmental gradients in estuaries depend on seasonal and daily fluctuations of abiotic factors.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Estuarine ecosystems are characterized by a constantly changing mixture of saltwater and freshwater (McLusky, 1989). Environmental gradients in estuaries depend on seasonal and daily fluctuations of abiotic factors.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-CAPITULO-DO-LIVRO: Fishery ecology in South American river basins
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-CAPITULO-DO-LIVRO-INGLES: Fishery ecology in South American river basins

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Inland fisheries are vital for the livelihoods and food resources of humans worldwide but their importance is underestimated, probably because large numbers of small, local operators are involved. Freshwater Fisheries Ecology defines what we have globally, what we are going to lose and mitigate for, and what, given the right tools, we can save. To estimate potential production, the dynamics of freshwater ecosystems (rivers, lakes and estuaries) need to be understood. These dynamics are diverse as are the earth?s freshwater fisheries resources (from boreal to tropical regions), and these influence how fisheries are both utilized and abused. Three main types of fisheries are described within the book: artisanal, commercial and recreational, and the tools which have evolved for fisheries governance and management, including assessment methods, are described. The book also covers in detail fisheries development, providing information on improving fisheries through environmental and habitat evaluation, enhancement and rehabilitation, aquaculture, genetically modified fishes and sustainability. The book thoroughly reviews the negative impacts on fisheries including excessive harvesting, climate change, toxicology, impoundments, barriers and abstractions, non-native species and eutrophication. Finally, key areas of future research are outlined.
Freshwater Fisheries Ecology is truly a landmark publication, containing contributions from over 100 leading experts and supported by the Fisheries Society of the British Isles. The global approach makes this book essential reading for fish biologists, fisheries scientists and ecologists and upper level students in these disciplines. Libraries in all universities and research establishments where biological and fisheries sciences are studied and taught should have

DETALHAMENTO-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-LIVRO: Biology, Ecology and Culture of Grey Mullets (Mugilidae)

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Mullets (grey mullets) are a family (Mugilidae) and order of ray-finned fish found in temperate and tropical waters worldwide. There are approximately 80 species of mullet; these fish have been considered an important food source in Mediterranean Europe since Roman times. This book provides a long overdue update on the biology and ecology of mullets and features comprehensive coverage of the key features of the Mugilidae family, such as recent DNA evidence and morphological data that challenge the traditional taxonomy.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Mullets (grey mullets) are a family (Mugilidae) and order of ray-finned fish found in temperate and tropical waters worldwide. This book provides a long overdue update on the biology and ecology of mullets and features comprehensive coverage of the key features of the Mugilidae family, such as recent DNA evidence and morphological data that challenge the traditional taxonomy.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-CAPITULO-DO-LIVRO: Estuarine Ecoclines and the Associated Fauna: Ecological Information as the Basis for Ecosystema Conservation
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-CAPITULO-DO-LIVRO-INGLES: Estuarine Ecoclines and the Associated Fauna: Ecological Information as the Basis for Ecosystema Conservation

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Ecocline is defined as a ?gradation from one ecosystem to another when
there is no sharp boundary between the two? containing relatively heterogeneous
communities influenced by gradual changes between river-dominated to marinelike
waters. It creates heterogeneous habitats, differing in abiotic characteristics,
mainly water salinity. Estuarine fish fauna is highly influenced by the major annual
water quality shifts resulted from seaward river flow during the rainy season and
upstream coastal water inflow during drier seasons. Thus, faunal communities
change seasonally in terms of quali-quantitative variables or living strategies.
Estuarine ecocline can also set the seasonal retention, bioavailability or sinking of
dissolved oxygen, pollutants and microbiological contaminants whose effects are
crucial to determine the pattern of use, fish entering, tissue contamination and survival
of early stages. Abrupt changes in climatic patterns or in the river flow induce
changes in the ecocline and fishes will respond by modifying assemblage structures.
The use of robust and consistent scientific information regarding fish fauna and their
ecocline can provide reliable ecological information. This generates descriptors of
reference conditions taking into account how human impacts affect coastal systems,
providing steps to guarantee the sustainable use of estuarine resources.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-CAPITULO-DO-LIVRO: How can Accurate Landing Stats Help Designing Better Fisheries and Environmental Management for Western Atlantic Estuaries?
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-CAPITULO-DO-LIVRO-INGLES: How can Accurate Landing Stats Help Designing Better Fisheries and Environmental Management for Western Atlantic Estuaries?

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Fisheries in Brazil, the country with most territory in South America, is
not comprehensive at all. The lack of precise historical data is the main concern
faced by perspectives of fishery management. The majority of data are simplistic
records of extrapolated biomass published by federal entities regardless the habitat
from where fish resources were harvested, how they were captured and lengths of
capture. Little attention was given to the social, economic and cultural aspects of
traditional communities and their livelihood. Worst is the case of estuarine systems
of the Western Atlantic, where artisanal fishery rules the landings and the absence
of proper monitoring, control and surveillance leads to poor managerial actions. As
a result, fishery studies conclude that most fish stocks of Western Atlantic estuaries
show signs of over-exploitation. Palliative measures such as closed periods for capture
of common resources has emerged as urgent option aiming to reduce the
impacts of overfishing. Bycatch reduction devices are examples of emerging

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TEXTO.TITULO-DO-TEXTO: Consequencia da mortalidade de raias Ticonha na Baia de Guanabara - RJ
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TEXTO.TITULO-DO-TEXTO-INGLES: A DISTRIBUIÇÃO ECOGEOGRAFICA DAS RAIAS NAS AMÉRICAS: com ênfase nas espécies de importância econômica.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
É importante esclarecer que a raia-ticonha (Rhinoptera bonasus) é um peixe cartilaginoso, e que costuma formar grandes cardumes. Esta espécie ocorre desde o sul da Nova Inglaterra (EUA) até o norte da Argentina, e normalmente se alimenta de moluscos e crustáceos. Ecologicamente, a raia-ticonha, pela atividade como predadora de algumas espécies e também como competidora de outras, desempenha um papel funcional na dinâmica dos ecossistemas marinhos, estuarinos e de água doce. Nesse sentido, reduções populacionais da espécie em questão podem levar a efeitos na teia alimentar e consequente modificação da composição (biodiversidade) da comunidade bentônica, que inclui moluscos e crustáceos. Mas, para entendermos melhor sobre as consequências da retirada desses predadores para a fauna bentônica, mais estudos deveriam ser realizados na Baía da Guanabara, principalmente onde essas raias foram encontradas, próximo à Ilha do Governador.

Quando adultas, as raias-ticonha utilizam diferentes áreas para reprodução (no verão) e alimentação (no inverno). O acasalamento ocorre anualmente ou a cada dois anos, e as fêmeas grávidas acessam as áreas de berçário para dar à luz. Algumas dessas áreas de berçário são conhecidas para algumas populações de raias-ticonha no hemisfério norte ? por isso, são áreas protegidas. No entanto, o conhecimento sobre a biologia das raias-ticonha no hemisfério sul é raro, com relatos ocasionais de potenciais áreas de berçário. Provavelmente, o cardume encontrado morto na Baía de Guanabara estaria a caminho dessa área para dar à luz seus filhotes. Isso revela que estudos básicos sobre aspectos da história de vida são necessários com urgência no Brasil.

A recuperação de populações de tubarões e raias impactados requer atenção em todas as faixas etárias. Fatores como recrutamento ? nascimento de filhotes e imigração de indivíduos ?, sobrevivência dos indivíduos adultos e proteção de áreas de berçário são importantes para a estabilidade das populações.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
The origins of this special issue date back to 2009, when a group of South American
fish scientists united to prepare a manuscript on Fish and aquatic habitat conservation
in South America for a Journal of Fish Biology special issue on the conservation
of fishes (Vol. 76, Number 9, June 2010). At that time, 18 co-authors from different
regions and backgrounds produced a paper that highlighted their main concerns
about fishes, fisheries and fish habitat conservation in South America (Barletta et al.,
2010). In this review, authors provided a diagnostic overview of the problems facing
the conservation of the fishes of South America, which once had the highest diversity
of fish species in the world. Habitat loss emerged as the greatest concern for all
South American aquatic ecosystems, with a long list of causes, including damming
of rivers, deforestation, pollution, mining and poor agricultural practices, characterized
by unsustainable development models. The decrease in number and diversity of
fishes is more than a conservation issue; South American countries are still developing
and food security is of equally great concern (Craig, 2016; Crosetti & Blaber, 2016).
Declining fisheries therefore have serious economic and social consequences. Most
of the conservation problems, including those of the main river basins, their estuaries
and marine coastal and open waters need to be addressed on a multinational basis;
harmonized management of trans-boundary waters is a necessity. Unfortunately, due
to deeply rooted governance issues, fisheries management is generally inadequate to
meet these challenges, and the authors concluded that change in the regional conservation
paradigm is required, involving integrated research and management (Barletta
et al., 2010). It is available on http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jfb.2016.89.issue-1/issuetoc

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Microplastics and other anthropogenic particle contamination and its potential trophic transfer in a tropical Andean reservoir

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Ecologia da contaminação de ecossistemas aguaticos

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: This study evaluated anthropogenic particle contamination in the water, sediment, and biota (i.e., microcrustaceans, macroinvertebrates, and fish) compartments at the downstream end of the tropical Andean reservoir. For this purpose, sampling was carried out at three hydrological periods between 2022 and 2023. The obtained samples were subjected to specific digestion for each environmental compartment and the identified particles were quantified and classified in size, shape, and color. The polymeric composition of particles in each compartment was analyzed by Fourier transform spectrophotometry. A correlation matrix allowed establishing the shared presence of microplastics between compartments. An ANOVA was used to evaluate statistical differences in particle size and quantity between sampling times for each compartment. Discriminant analysis was used to evaluate the relationship of fish feeding habits with the quantity of particles found in fish. Anthropogenic particles (including some outside of the scope of this study) were found in all abiotic and biotic compartments. Blue fibers were predominant in all compartments, with omnivorous fish exhibiting the highest particle concentration. Microplastics comprised 12% of the particles, mainly polypropylene, polyester, polyethylene and polyvinyl chloride. The remaining particles were rayon, cellulose and cotton. A conceptual model addressing the dynamics of pollution in Peñol-Guatapé reservoir is proposed, suggesting how anthropogenic particles transfer between environmental compartments and species.

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: Long term monitoring of a semi-arid climate river basin contributing to a tropical estuary

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 50th ECSA Conference: Today's science for tomorrow's Management

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
The Brazilian Northeast coast has many small rivers. The tropical semi-arid climate puts the scarce and heavily used superficial water resources at risk. The coastal population depends on these basins for water supply and nature conservation. The Goiana River basin is formed by three rivers. Ecological studies in the estuary use water physical-chemical parameters as environmental descriptors. The main parameters in the present study are temperature (oC), pH, Dissolved Oxygen (DO) (mg.L-1), Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD) (mg.L-1), Turbidity (UNT), Total Phosphorus (TP) (mg.L-1), Faecal Coliforms (FC) (NMP.100mL-1), Salinity (?) and monthly total Rainfall (mm). Data 
are from a 20+ years monitoring program (1992-present) conducted by the Environmental Agency, and three sampling stations at the head of the estuary are used divided in dry and rainy seasons according to rainfall. Temperature ranged from 31.50 (±0.88) to 26.50 (±1.50) in the dry and 30.00 (±0.00) to 23.00 (±0.00) in the rainy season; pH from 8.20 (±0.13) to 6.35 (±0.04) and 7.86 (±0.13) to 6.80 (±0.00); DO from 7.54 (±0.52) to 0.00 (±0.00) and 7.08 (±1.35) to 1.80 (±0.00); BOD from 70.00 
(±117.09) to 0.90 (±0.36) and 8.20 (±0.00) to 0.50 (±0.00); Turbidity from 69.67 (±59.37) to 10.33 (±4.51) and 285.00 (±24.75) to 15.00 (±0.00); TP from 1.72 (±2.36) to 0.06 (±0.03) and 1.51 (±0.00) to 0.07 (±0.00); FC from 160,000 (±0) to 200 (±0) and 140,000 (±0) to 200 (±0); ; Salinity from 6.01 (±5.62) to 0.18 (±0.01) and 6.40 (±0.00) to 0.13 (±0.05) ;and Rainfall from 114.00 (±119.00) to 28.33 (±14.22) and 344.00 (±0.00) to 0.00 (±0.00) respectively. Statistical analyses detect temporal variations between seasons and among years. The dry season has the lesser water quality. An initial 
model was created using some of the parameters to explain/predict BOD. Other models can also be proposed for TP and FC. Keywords: Environmental Monitoring, Estuarine Conservation, South America, Goiana River Estuary

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: A four years data series of water physico-chemical variables in a tropical estuary (Northeast Brazil): Ecological and conservation implications

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 50th ECSA Conference: Today's science for tomorrow's Management

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
A sample strategy considering three areas and four seasons was deployed 
during four years (2005-2009) in the Goiana Estuary. Five water variables were 
measured from 1060 samples (surface and bottom). Rainfall showed annual and 
seasonal interactions (F(3,836)=35.729, p<0.0001). The lowest means occurred in 
the late dry season (LD) of the first (21.28mm) and third (40mm) years. The 
highest mean was in the late rainy season (LR) of the second year (315.2mm). 
Water physico-chemical variables showed significant interaction among factors 
Year (I, II, III, IV) vs Season (LR, LD) vs Area of the estuary (Upper, Middle, 
Lower). Temperature showed the lowest means during LR in the third year in the 
Upper and Middle (~26°C). The highest means were during LD in the same years 
in the Lower (~30 °C). Salinity showed the lowest means during LR in the Upper 
(~0) and Middle (~0.3) in all years. The highest means were during LD in the 
Lower in the first year (~32). Dissolved Oxygen showed the lowest means during 
LD in the Upper (~3.2mg.L-1) and Middle (~4mg.L-1) in the third and second year. 
The Lower showed the highest means during LR (~7.1mg.L-1) in the fourth year 
and during LD (~7.5mg.L-1) in the first year. Dissolved Oxygen percent saturation 
showed the lowest mean during LD in the Upper in the third and second years 
(41 and 43.4%, respectively). The highest means were in the Lower during LR 
(~89.2%) in the fourth and during LD (~95.6%) in the first year. Secchi depth 
showed the lowest means in the Upper (~20.8cm) and Middle (~25.7cm) estuary 
during LR in the first year. The highest mean were in the lower during the LD in 
the third (142.4cm) and first (1.55cm) years. Water flows to coastal ecosystems 
(reefs, sandy beaches and seagrass meadows) of significance for fisheries and 
conservation. 
Keywords: Environmental monitoring, Time series, Climate change, Aquatic conservation

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: Physiographic evolution model of a tropical estuary surroundings located in the Western South Atlantic

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 50th ECSA Conference: Today's science for tomorrow's Management

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Multitemporal observations (MO) used satellite imagery to study the Goiana 
Estuary ecosystem dynamics. This approach effectively detects changes in 
different times on local land cover and physiographic aspects, which were 
accessed using georeferenced raster format topographic maps, Landsat TM and 
CBERS imagery covering non-subsequent years from 1972 to 2010 in order to 
analyze the dynamics of coastal resource exploitation, land degradation, 
ecological patterns and processes. Information extracted from topographic maps, 
covering the year of 1972, served as a prime to attribute six classes out of nine to 
the supervised classification scheme. Classes identified in the images were 
defined as follows: Atlantic Rain Forest (ARF), mangrove forest (MF), coconut 
plantation (CP), roads, shrimp ponds (SP), cement industry (CI), sugar-cane 
plantation (SCP), water bodies and urban area (UA). These classes represent 
spatial features that may change in response to natural and/or anthropogenic 
pressures. Based on these data, a GLM model estimates the ARF cover area 
(ha) in function of SCP increase area around the estuary. The proposed model is 
represented by the function ARF = 67720 ? 3.763SCP ? 9.88CP + 0.0005SCP*CP. Based on this model ARF areas were predicted as a function of an increase of the total SCP area in 1, 2 and 3% for 2015, 2018 and 2021. Keywords: land use, Time series, ecological modeling, estuarine conservation

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: Spatial, temporal and ontogenetic diet overlaps among sympatric catfishes that use a tropical estuary as nursery

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 50th ECSA Conference: Today's science for tomorrow's Management

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
This study describes the seasonal feeding habits of different size classes of 
Cathorops spixii and Cathorops agassizii along an estuarine ecocline, and the 
food overlap when different size classes occur together. Seasonal freshwater 
discharge influenced the fluctuation of environmental conditions (salinity and 
dissolved oxygen) and was important to define the habitat utilization of different 
ontogenetic phases of these species along the estuarine ecocline. These species 
are expected to be zoobenthivorous, but along their life cycle and between 
different habitats and seasons, this trophic guild can change to zooplanktivore. 
During the early dry season, in the upper and middle estuary, sub-adults and 
adults of C. spixii showed a diet overlap, mainly by the high ingestion of 
Polychaeta and Ostracoda. During the late dry season, in the upper estuary, 
adults of C. spixii showed diet overlap with juveniles and adults of C. agassizii, 
principally due to the high ingestion of Gastropoda, Ostracoda and Calanoida. 
During the early rainy season, in the upper estuary, were observed significant 
diet overlap between juveniles of both species, sub-adults of both species and 
between juveniles and sub-adults of C. agassizii, influenced by the high ingestion 
of Ostracoda and Calanoida. During the late rainy season, in the middle estuary, 
diet overlap occurred between juveniles and sub-adults of C. spixii and C. 
agassizii, with high ingestion of Gastropoda, Calanoida and Harpacticoida. At this 
time, in the lower estuary C. spixii and C. agassizii juveniles, and sub-adults 
showed remarkable diet overlap, with high ingestion of Gastropoda, Ostracoda 
and Calanoida. The knowledge of feeding habits and habitat utilization by 
different ontogenetic phases is essential to understand the ecological role of fish 
populations, a critical tool in the development of conservation and management 
plans. 
Keywords: feeding habitats, Cathorops spp., estua

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: Spatial and seasonal patterns of resources partitioning between sympatric fish species that use an estuarine ecocline as nursery habitats

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 50th ECSA Conference: Today's science for tomorrow's Management

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Habitats utilization by fish relates with diet shifts during the life cycle. Diet 
analysis of different ontogenetic phases from different habitats provides 
information about movement patterns between nursery and adult habitats. This 
study describes the seasonal habitat utilization and feeding habits of different 
ontogenetic phases of Stellifer brasiliensis and S. stellifer along an estuarine 
ecocline, and the food overlap when different ontogenetic phases occur together. 
Seasonal freshwater discharge influenced the fluctuation of environmental 
conditions (salinity and water temperature) and was important to define the 
habitat utilization of different ontogenetic phases of these species along the 
estuarine ecocline. The middle estuary was important as nursery and feeding 
ground for juveniles, and feeding ground for sub-adults and adults of both 
species. These species are normally zoobenthivorous, but along their life cycle 
and between different habitats and seasons, this trophic guild can change to 
opportunist or zooplanktivore. During the late rainy season in the lower estuary 
all phases of both species, except juveniles of S. brasiliensis and adults of S. 
stellifer, showed a diet overlap indicating similarity in prey utilization. This overlap 
results from the consumption of Calanoida, Polychaeta and Eucarida by all 
phases of both species. Moreover, The ingestion of blue nylon fragments by 
these species was an environmental problem, which solutions are in the hands of 
authorities and communities alike. The knowledge of feeding habits and habitat 
utilization by different ontogenetic phases is essential to understand the 
ecological role of fish populations, a critical tool in the development of 
conservation and management plans. 
Keywords: fish assemblages, onthogenetic development, nursery concept, 
ecological services

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: Ecology of Microplastic and Mercury contamination within food webs of estuarine and coastal ecosystems
DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO-INGLES: Ecology of Microplastic and Mercury contamination within food webs of estuarine and coastal ecosystems

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Latin American and Caribbean Fishery Congress

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Studies in tropical estuaries have demonstrated that Cathorops spixii and C. agassizii contribute more than 50% of the total density and 70% of the total biomass of the estuarine ecosystem, respectively. These species play an important role in the food web as a food resource for top predatory species, such as Acoupa weakfish (Cynoscion acoupa). The distribution of the different ontogenetic phases of C. spixii and C. agassizii in the estuarine ecosystems are influenced by the seasonal fluctuations of the saline ecocline. In this estuary, each ontogenetic phase of these marine catfishes responds differently to the seasonal fluctuation of these environmental variables. It suggests that by their exposition of the seasonal fluctuations of the gradient of salinity, the ontogenetic phases of these species can reflect the environmental conditions of the portion of the estuary that they are using at that moment. A study on T-Hg contamination in adults of C. spixii in the Goiana River estuary indicated that during the dry season, there was a greater concentration of the metal (600-1400 µgT-Hg. kg-1) in the lower portion of the estuary. The coefficient of determination of the linear regression between the specimens? T-Hg concentration in the muscle vs. total weight suggests that other variables could help to explain the contamination by T-HG in this species. Based on this information, the hypothesis tested in this study was that the seasonal fluctuation of the gradient of salinity and rainfall in the tropical estuary could influence the T-Hg concentration in individuals of the marine catfish species throughout their development. In the upper estuary, the lowest values of Hg-T contamination were found for both species (). In this portion of the estuary, the highest concentration of T-Hg was found in sub-adult and adult individuals of C. spixii. Both species followed the same behavior, where individuals from the latter ontogenetic phase were more contaminated by mercury than t

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Ecologia da contaminação de ecossistemas aguaticos

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Plastic particle occurrence in the digestive tracts of fishes from a tropical estuarine system in the Gulf of Cali­fornia was investigated. A total of 1095 fish were analysed, representing 15 species. In total 1384 particles of plastic debris were recovered from the gastrointestinal tracts of 552 specimens belonging to 13 species, and all consisted of threads, the majority of which we.re small microplastics (0.23 to 1.89), followed by large micro­plastics (2.07 to 4.49), and few mesoplastics (5.4 to 19.86). Plastic particles were identified using ATR-FTIR spectoscopy. The mean frequency of occurrence of plastics in the gastrointestinal tracts of fishes from this system was 50.5%, which is higher than frequencies reported in similar systems in other areas. The polymers identified by ATR-FTIR were polyamide (51.2%), polyethylene (36.6%), polypropylene (7.3%), and polyac1ylic ( 4. 9%). These results show the fist evidence of plastic contan1ination for estuarine biota in the Gulf of California.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Plastic particle occurrence in the digestive tracts of fishes from a tropical estuarine system in the Gulf of Cali­fornia was investigated. Plastic particles were identified using ATR-FTIR spectoscopy. These results show the fist evidence of plastic contan1ination for estuarine biota in the Gulf of California.

A total of 30 fish were analysed, representing 5 species. In total all fishes werecontamined by particles of plastic debris were recovered from the gastrointestinal tracts, and all consisted of threads, the majority of which we.re small microplastics (0.23 to 1.89), followed by large micro­plastics (2.07 to 4.49), and few mesoplastics (5.4 to 19.86). Plastic particles will be identified using ATR-FTIR spectoscopy. The mean frequency of occurrence of plastics in the gastrointestinal tracts of fishes from this system was 50.5%, which is higher than frequencies reported in similar systems in other areas.

DADOS-BASICOS-DE-EDITORACAO.TITULO: Journal of Fish Biology Special Issue: Fish and aquatic habitat conservation in South America
DADOS-BASICOS-DE-EDITORACAO.TITULO-INGLES: Journal of Fish Biology Special Issue: Fish and aquatic habitat conservation in South America

DETALHAMENTO-DE-EDITORACAO.INSTITUICAO-PROMOTORA: © The Fisheries Society of the British Isles

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
After meetings at a number of international conferences across the South American continent, a symposium entitled Fish and Aquatic Habitat Conservation in South America was convened
during the XXI Brazilian Ichthyology Meeting in Recife (Brazil) in 2015. The present special issue of Journal of Fish Biology contains 65 papers (31 freshwater, 18 estuarine and 16 marine) on South American fishes, their habitats and conservation, mainly from the Recife symposium. The biomes and ecosystems analysed by Barletta et al. (2010, 2016) are now analysed in greater depth and with updated details. This collection of papers, written by over 200 authors, contains a number of significant reviews, including an overview of fish biodiversity and conservation in South America (Reis et al., 2016) and a discussion of special challenges in South America (Costa & Barletta, 2016). In relation to fresh waters, Jimenez-Segura et al. (2016) review the situation in the Caribbean area of the continent, Lopez-Casas et al. (2016) the Magdelena Basin and Lasso et al. (2016) the Orinoco Basin. In the southern
part of the continent, the situation in Patagonia is described by Cussac et al. (2016)
and in the Patos Lagoon by Fontoura et al. (2016). Invasions of South American fresh
waters by exotic species are reviewed byWeyl et al. (2016) for Clarias gariepinus and
by Crichigno et al. (2016) for Cyprinus carpio. An overview of estuarine fish research
in South America is provided by Blaber & Barletta (2016) and the situation in the La
Plata Estuary is reviewed in detail by Jaureguizar et al. (2016), while Saint-Paul &
Schneider (2016) describe the role of Brazilian-German collaborative research in the
mangrove areas of northern Brazil. In addition, a number of scientists have expressed, in letters to the community, their opinions and experiences in relation to conservation and management of freshwater basins such as the Magdalena, Orinoco, Amazon, São Francisco, Paraná, Andean Piedmont, as well

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Despite of inequality of scientific information on the different regions of South American ecosystems, it is evident that the impacts caused by developing pressure are in different levels almost the same. The information, most grey literature, is concentrated close the governamental institutions distributed strategically on the continent. However, it is clear that there is a great lack of the information about ecology, biology, taxonomy, and socio-economic in each analysed biome that should be at least takes into account to the manajement. Moreover, most of this biome overcomes the boundaries of the political division of the continent. In adition, the absence or unefficacy of international environmental politics most of these biome are not under the same management program. However, when it happens prevails, most of the time, the economic and developing interes. Metigations actions, when it occurs, are realized whith out scientific planejament. Most of the case because the lack of biotic and abiotic data and political interess.
Understanding the effects of short and large scale patterns in abiotic conditions is necessary for a more complete understanding of ecosystems ecology including their energy flux and connectivity among habitats, the fisheries dynamics and therefore, effective management. The linkage between the ecosystem and management practice is provide by solid ecological knowledge and understanding of the dynamics of the source and the ecosystem in which it operate. Of major importance is an understanding of how the productivity of these fisheries may be influenced by habitats connectivity process and particularly by human-induced perturbations in the integridade of these connections (Blaber, 2009). This review gives an idea of environment influence on fish comunity distribution dynamics, habitat conectivity and ecological studies (including sample strategies and design) are needed to develop a future coastal, estuarine and riverine basin management inte

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: PAULO DE TARSO DA CUNHA CHAVES

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The proposal would be a multidisciplinary research project, to be developed in 4 + 4 years. The main objective would be to assess the termohaline structure and water movements around different seamounts; nutrient contents in relation to the prevailing hydrographic phenomena; primary and secondary productivity processes; distribution and condition of fish larvae; possible recruitment processes; genetic characteristics of local populations of key aquatic animals; and the influence of physical and biological processes on fisheries activities. The data already available have shown, for instance, that the most pronounced influence of the submarine relief on the hydrographic conditions seems to happen in those seamounts which depths range from 150 to 250 m, roughly coinciding with the depth at the bottom of the thermocline. When the seamount is too shallow or in a case of an Island, the high static stability caused by the steep thermocline prevents the subthermocline water to upwell above the seamount. When the top of the seamount, however, is located just below the thermocline, the denser water is able to speed up above the seamount, gaining vorticity and possibly resulting in upwelling and eventual formation of a Taylor column. The upwelled water might then promote an increase of nutrient contents in shallower layers, with a much higher light intensity, what in turn might result in an increased primary productivity. Preliminary data on the vertical distribution of chlorophyll have indicated that the maximum concentrations are found close to the bottom of the thermocline, at about 1% of light intensity. The eddies that are likely generated might also cause convergence or divergence of water, not only influencing the processes of primary productivity, but also the distribution of fish larvae, directly affecting the recruitment process and reproductive strategy of local fish populations. Many demersal fish species inhabiting oceanic islands and seamounts, for instance, ar

DADOS-BASICOS-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-.TITULO: Variação sazonalda biomassa e densidade das espécies de peixes da família Ariidae no estuário da Baía de Paranaguá

DETALHAMENTO-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-P.NOME-DA-AGENCIA: Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Estudos realizados em estuários de regiões tropicais e subtropicais têm mostrado a importância da Família Ariidae para esses ecossistemas. No Estuário de Paranaguá, esta família é uma das mais abundantes, tanto em número de indivíduos quanto em peso. O presente estudo teve como objetivo principal estudar a variação espacial e temporal da densidade e biomassa dos peixes pertencentes à Família Ariidae no Estuário de Paranaguá. As amostragens foram realizadas mensalmente, entre junho/2000 e julho/2001, em três regiões do estuário (superior, intermediária e inferior). Os arrastos foram realizados com rede de arrasto com portas. Em cada área amostral foram realizadas seis réplicas. A análise de agrupamento dos dados abióticos (temperatura e salinidade) definiu dois grupos principais. O primeiro grupo compreendeu as amostras coletadas no estuário superior, e o segundo grupo foi formado pelas amostras dos estuários intermediário e inferior. As espécies da Família Ariidae contribuíram com uma densidade total de 766 ind.ha-1 (51%) e uma biomassa total de 26 kg.ha-1 (76%). Essa família foi representada pelas espécies Cathorops spixii, Genidens genidens, Aspistor luniscutis, G. barbus e Arius parkeri. C. spixii foi a espécie mais freqüente nesse ecossistema, com 49% de freqüência de ocorrência dentre todas as espécies encontradas, contribuindo com uma densidade total de 686 ind.ha-1 (45%) e uma biomassa total de 20 kg.ha-1 (60%). A biomassa de C. spixii variou significativamente, tanto entre regiões do estuário quanto entre estações do ano (p<0,01), com os maiores valores no estuário médio, no início da estação chuvosa. A densidade de C. spixii apresentou diferenças significativas entre regiões do estuário (p<0,05), com maiores valores no estuário médio. A densidade de G. genidens (p<0,05) e a biomassa de A. luniscutis (p<0,01) também apresentaram diferenças significativas em relação às regiões do estuário, com maiores valores no estuário superior. DADOS-BASICOS-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-.TITULO: Variação da composição da assembléia de peixes no Estuário de Paranaguá - PR. Sazonalidade ou impacto de um processo de dragagem?

DETALHAMENTO-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-P.NOME-DO-ORIENTADO: Adriana Alves Corrêa Ribeiro do Couto
DETALHAMENTO-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-P.NOME-DA-AGENCIA: Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-3: Política Econômica e Administração Pública em Geral

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Este estudo teve por objetivo verificar a variância na composição da assembléia de peixes (número de espécies, densidade e biomassa) em uma área do Estuário de Paranaguá, comparando as situações antes (maio/2001), durante (setembro/2001) e depois (março/2002) de um processo de dragagem com o mesmo período do ano anterior. Em cada período amostral foram realizados seis arrastos, três amostras no canal dragado e três amostras na área adjacente ao canal, onde foi depositado o rejeito dragado. Para o acompanhamento da variância sazonal na composição específica, da densidade e biomassa foram utilizadas informações dos meses de junho/2000, setembro/2000 e março/2001. No ano do processo de dragagem, foram capturadas 31 espécies de peixes, representando uma densidade média total de 1,76 ind./m2 e biomassa média total de 103,99 g/m2. Cathorops spixii foi a espécie mais importante, tanto na densidade total (46,92%) quanto na biomassa total (76,22%). Nos meses do ano anterior ao processo de dragagem (junho/2000, setembro/2000 e março/2001), foram capturadas 38 espécies, apresentando densidade média total de 0,28 ind./m2 e biomassa média total de 2,79 g/m2. Stellifer rastrifer foi a espécie que apresentou a maior densidade total (66,12%) e C. spixii apresentou a maior biomassa total (48,78%) neste caso. De acordo com os resultados da ANOVA e Kruskal-Wallis, no ano da dragagem foram observadas diferenças significativas e interação entre os fatores período (pré-dragagem, dragagem e 
pós dragagem) e local (canal principal e área adjacente) para o número de espécies (p<0,05). Diferenças significativas foram observadas para densidade total (p<0,05), densidade de Genidens barbus (p<0,05) e Menthicirrhus americanus (p<0,05). A biomassa foi significativamente diferente para G. barbus (p<0,01), Genidens genidens (p<0,05) e para M. americanus (p<0,05) onde também ocorreu interação entre os fatores
período e local. Podemos assim afirmar que o processo de dragagem influenciou na distrib

DETALHAMENTO-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-P.NOME-DO-CURSO: Ciências Geodésicas e Tecnologias da Geoinformação
DETALHAMENTO-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-P.NOME-DA-AGENCIA: Coordenação de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Cartografia Básica

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Os levantamentos hidrográficos são elaborados, para fornecer documentos cartográficos e informações que sirvam de apoio ao comércio marítimo, navegação, segurança nacional, estudos científicos, fornecimento de dados básicos aos empreendimentos de engenharia e para outras necessidades comerciais e industriais. Englobam atividades de campo (sondagem e posicionamento) e escritório (processamento e pós-processamento dos dados de campo). O objetivo principal do trabalho consiste em executar um levantamento da superfície de fundo do estuário do Rio Goiana, obedecendo aos padrões internacionais e recomendações da Marinha do Brasil durante o planejamento, amostragem e processamento das medições verticais e posicionamento horizontal ao longo da área estudada. O levantamento será efetuado utilizando ecossonda de feixe único para medição das profundidades, combinada com um sistema diferencial de posicionamento horizontal (DGPS. Para a pesquisa, ao invés do levantamento tradicional, usando observações maregráficas ao longo da área estudada, é proposto o uso de soluções GPS para o ajuste da componente de maré usada para a redução das sondagens. Com a conclusão do levantamento é esperado que se obtenha conhecimento detalhado sobre a morfologia do fundo marinho ao longo da área de estudos, fornecendo uma matriz topográfica que pode integrar estudos futuros, bem como os que já se encontram em andamento. Esta pesquisa fará grandes contribuições para as ciências do mar, no âmbito nacional e estadual, fornecendo informações precisas que favorecem o entendimento da complexidade das variáveis geográficas que interagem e compõem os ambientes costeiros do Brasil.

DADOS-BASICOS-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-.TITULO: Distribuição espaço-temporal e ecologia alimentar das diferentes fases ontogenéticas de Achirus lineatus (Linnaeus, 1758) no estuário do Rio Goiana (PE/PB).

DETALHAMENTO-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-P.NOME-DA-AGENCIA: Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Estuários são ecossistemas costeiros, onde a água salgada do mar e o aporte fluvial se encontram e se misturam. É utilizado como local de alimentação, proteção, reprodução e berçário para diversos organismos marinhos. Espécimes da família Achiridae pertencem a um importante grupo ecológico de ecossistemas estuarinos, os demersais. Esses organismos vivem e se alimentam da matéria orgânica disponível no substrato, e ao serem predados por outros organismos promovem um elo na teia trófica. O estudo da distribuição e ecologia alimentar é extremamente relevante para o entendimento do ciclo de vida de peixes estuarinos, pois permite um planejamento sustentável do recurso pesqueiro, além de fornecer dados sobre a saúde ambiental, possibilitando assim medidas mitigatórias e de conservação. O objetivo desse estudo é descrever a variação espacial e temporal na dieta das diferentes fases ontogenéticas da espécie Achirus lineatus (Linnaeus, 1758) e determinar a influência dos fatores ambientais em sua distribuição ao longo dos diversos habitats do estuário do Rio Goiana. O estuário do Rio Goiana localiza-se na região Nordeste do Brasil na divisa dos estados de Pernambuco e Paraíba, região com clima tropical. As coletas foram realizadas no ano de 2005, no período de chuva e estiagem, diversos habitats do estuário foram amostrados.

DADOS-BASICOS-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-.TITULO: Distribuição espaço-temporal e ecologia alimentar das diferentes fases ontogenéticas de Pomadasys crocro (Cuvier, 1830) no estuário do Rio Goiana (PE/PB).
DADOS-BASICOS-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-.TITULO-INGLES: Use of Resources and Microplastic Contamination throughout the Life Cycle of Grunts (Haemulidae) in a Tropical Estuary

DETALHAMENTO-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-P.NOME-DA-AGENCIA: Coordenação de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The distribution, feeding ecology and microplastic contamination were assessed in different ontogenetic phases of Haemulidae species inhabiting the Goiana Estuary, over a seasonal cycle. Pomadasys ramosus and Haemulopsis corvinaeformis are estuarine dependent species that use habitats with specific environmental conditions each season. Pomadasys ramosus was found in the upper and middle estuaries during the rainy season, when salinity showed the lowest values. Haemulopsis corvinaeformis was found in the lower estuary during the dry season, when salinity increases in the estuary. Juveniles of P. ramosus are zooplanktivores, feeding mainly on calanoid copepods. Sub-adults and adults are zoobenthivores, feeding on invertebrates associated to the bottom, mainly Polychaeta. Juveniles of H. corvinaeformis were not found in the main channel, but sub-adults and adults showed a zoobenthivore habit, feeding mainly on Anomalocardia flexuosa (Mollusca: Bivalvia). Dietary shifts along the life cycle and the spatio-temporal relationship between their distribution and the availability of microplastics along the estuary seem to have a strong influence in the ingestion of microfilaments. The highest average ingestion of microfilaments by P. ramosus coincided with the peak of ingestion of Polychaeta by sub-adults in the upper estuary during the late rainy season. For H. corvinaeformis the highest ingestion of microfilaments coincided with the peak of ingestion of A. flexuosa by adults in the lower estuary during the late dry season. Such contamination might be attributed to the time when these phases shifted to a more diverse diet and began to forage on benthic invertebrates. Research on microplastic contamination must consider species-specific behaviour, since the intake of microplastics is dependent on patterns of distribution and trophic guild within fish assemblages.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: The distribution, feeding ecology and microplastic contamination were assessed in different ontogenetic phases of Haemulidae species inhabiting the Goiana Estuary, over a seasonal cycle. Juveniles of P. ramosus are zooplanktivores, feeding mainly on calanoid copepods. Sub-adults and adults are zoobenthivores, feeding on invertebrates associated to the bottom, mainly Polychaeta. The highest average ingestion of microfilaments by P. ramosus coincided with the peak of ingestion of Polychaeta by sub-adults in the upper estuary during the late rainy season. Research on microplastic contamination must consider species-specific behaviour, since the intake of microplastics is dependent on patterns of distribution and trophic guild within fish assemblages.

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: This study aims to evaluate the ecology of total Hg contamination in species of marine catfish Cathorops spixii and Cathorops agassizii, in relation to their phases ontogenetics, seasons, and salinity gradient in the Goiana river Estuary. In addition, it will be tested to test the hypothesis that seasonal fluctuation of abiotic parameters (e.g. gradient of salinity, temperature, and oxygen levels), spatio-temporal distribution, and food ecology influence total Hg concentration in individuals of catfish species (C. spixii and C. agassizii) throughout their development.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: This study aims to evaluate the ecology of total Hg contamination in species of marine catfish Cathorops spixii and Cathorops agassizii, in relation to their phases ontogenetics, seasons, and salinity gradient in the Goiana river Estuary. In addition, it will be tested to test the hypothesis that seasonal fluctuation of abiotic parameters (e.g. gradient of salinity, temperature, and oxygen levels), spatio-temporal distribution, and food ecology influence total Hg concentration in individuals of catfish species (C. spixii and C. agassizii) throughout their development.

DADOS-BASICOS-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-.TITULO: Ecologia alimentar e contaminação por microplásticos em Rhizoprionodon porosus na Zona Costeira do Estado de Pernambuco
DADOS-BASICOS-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-.TITULO-INGLES: Ecologia alimentar e contaminação por microplásticos em Rhizoprionodon porosus na Zona Costeira do Estado de Pernambuco

DETALHAMENTO-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-P.NOME-DO-ORIENTADO: Roger Rafael Cavalcanti Bandeira de Melo
DETALHAMENTO-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-P.NOME-DA-AGENCIA: Fundação de Amparo à Ciência e Tecnologia do Estado de Pernambuco

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-ESPECIALIDADE: Interação entre os Organismos Marinhos e os Parâmetros Ambientais

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-2.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Ecologia da contaminação de ecossistemas aguaticos

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The IUCN (UN) warns that the data currently obtained on the conservation status of the species Rhizoprionodon porosus are deficient. Contamination of the species associated with plastics is little studied, indicating the lack of information on contamination of elasmobranchs by microplastic. Therefore, it justifies the need to conduct studies on microplastic contamination in R. porosus. Contamination by microplastics occurs in a dispersed way in the ecosystem and is generally introduced in the environment as a result of improper treatment of solid waste and sewage. With the degradation of plastics in the environment, smaller particles are formed. When smaller than 5mm these pollutants are called microplastics. They are the most common types of marine plastic pollutants and the likelihood of ingestion of these particles by aquatic fauna is considered high. Despite the efforts of the UN, which calls for an entire decade of preservation to improve global environmental conditions, governmental and social efforts to preserve these habitats are still insignificant. And the lack of data on the ecology of coastal species hampers the few preventive measures adopted. This study will generate knowledge about the diet and microplastic contamination of R. porosus sharks. Based on this information, it will be possible to test the hypothesis that food preferences and contamination are correlated with their ontogenetic phases and the relationship of variation in capture and microplastic contamination of individuals at different times of the year (rain and drought) in the coastal region. The evaluation of the present study will be done through stomach and intestinal samples of R. porosus sharks obtained in the Coastal Zone of the State of Pernambuco. Expanding and updating the knowledge of its trophic ecology, sharing resources and competition between species, in addition to assisting the understanding, preservation and management of its populations.

DADOS-BASICOS-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-.TITULO: ECOLOGIA ALIMENTAR E DA CONTAMINAÇÂO POR MICROPLÁSTICO DAS DIFERENTES FASES ONTOGENÉTICAS DE UMA ESPÉCIE PLANCTÓFAGA NO ESTUÁRIO DO RIO GOIANA ? RESEX ACAÚ-GOIANA (PE/PB)

DETALHAMENTO-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-P.NOME-DA-AGENCIA: Fundação de Amparo à Ciência e Tecnologia do Estado de Pernambuco

PALAVRAS-CHAVE.PALAVRA-CHAVE-3: flutuação sazonal da biomassa e densidade

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Este estudo descreve a distribuição, ecologia alimentar e contaminação nas
diferentes fases ontogenéticas de A. clupeoides e C. edentulus no estuário,
onde a espécie estuarina A. cluepoides apresentou maior densidade na porção
superior do estuário durante o final da seca em adultos, em juvenis a maior
densidade foi na porção inferior do estuário durante o final da chuva onde essa
área é considerada berçário para essa espécie. A espécie marinha, estuarino
dependente, C. edentulus, apresentou maior densidade na porção superior do
estuário durante o final da seca, com a ausência de juvenis se sugere que o
berçário fica na região costeira, eles aproveitam a temporada da seca para
ingressar ao estuário e completar seu ciclo de vida. A dieta de A. cluepoides
consistiu principalmente por espécimenes de Copepodas, Larvas de
Gastropoda, Larvas de Anomalocardia sp e Larvas de Decapoda Zoe onde
houve uma preferência alimentar por zooplâncton em todas as fases
ontogenéticas. Segundo a media para essa espécie os maiores valores foram
copepoda na porção inferior do estuário durante o início da chuva em adultos,
Larvas de Anomalocardia sp na porção inferior do estuário durante o início da
seca em subadultos e em juvenis foram larvas de Gastropoda na porção
intermediária durante o início da seca. Em C. edentulus a alimentação consistiu
principalmente em Coscinodiscus sp, Actinopthycus sp, Chaetoceros sp e
Copepoda, onde a preferência desta espécie foi pelo fitoplâncton em todas as
fases ontogenéticas estudadas. Os maiores valores de FO% para essa espécie
foram Coscinodiscus sp e Actinopthycus sp na porção inferior do estuário no
final da chuva em adultos; Coscinodiscus sp e Actinopthycus sp na porção
inferior do estuário no final da seca e copepoda na poção superior do estuário
durante o final da seca em subadultos. A contaminação por microplásticos
(MPs) em A. clupeoides mostrou uma contaminação de fibras pretas, azuis,
vermelhas e verdes onde as fibras p

DADOS-BASICOS-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-.TITULO-INGLES: Ecologia das diferentes fases ontogeneticas de Cathorops spixii, C. agassizii, Achius lineatus e Stellifer rastrifer. Descricao dos diferentes habitas utilizados como bercario em ecossistema estuarino

DETALHAMENTO-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-P.NOME-DA-AGENCIA: Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Habitats utilization is related to diet shifts during the life-cycles, and diet analysis of different ontogenetic phases from different habitats provides information about movement patterns between nursery and adult habitats. This study described the seasonal habitat utilization and feeding habits of different ontogenetic phases of Stellifer brasiliensis (Sb) and S. stellifer (Ss) along an estuarine ecocline, and the food overlap when different ontogenetic phases of both species occur together. Seasonal freshwater discharge was important to define the habitat utilization of different ontogenetic phases of these species along the estuarine ecocline. The middle estuary was important as nursery and feeding ground for juveniles, and feeding ground for sub-adults and adults of both species. These species are expected to be zoobenthivorous, but along their life-cycle and between different habitats and seasons, their trophic guild can change to opportunist and/or zooplanktivore. During the late rainy season in the lower estuary all phases of both species, except juveniles of Sb and adults of Ss, showed a diet overlap indicating similarity in prey utilization. This overlap was influenced by the consumption of Calanoida, Polychaeta and Eucarida by all phases of both species. The ingestion of nylon fragments was observed as an environmental problem. Information on feeding habits and habitat utilization by different ontogenetic phases is essential to understand the ecological role of fish populations, critical in the development of conservation and management plans.
